author: smixxtape
content: Had a question about `finalized`, the part thats confusing me is that lets say Epoch `147196` is `finalized`, it consists of slots `4,710,272` to `4,710,303`…if I call `beacon/blocks/finalized` to get the latest finalized slot it returns `4,710,272` which is the first slot in that epoch, shouldn't it return the last slot if the whole epoch is considered `finalized`?

author: pietjepuk
content: No, afaik the state at the slot you get returned is finalized. Not anything after. This is often the block of the first slot of an epoch, but doesn't have to be (could also be a block in the previous epoch).

author: smixxtape
content: I guess my new question is “what does a finalized epoch mean”? I would assume (seemingly incorrectly) that the slots in that epoch are themselves finalized.

author: pietjepuk
content: I guess that's how I would interpret that as well. Your endpoint though is not asking for the last finalized epoch, it's asking for the last finalized block/state/etc. And it returns that correctly.

author: smixxtape
content: Correct if you get the latest finalized epoch or look on https://beaconscan.com/ the slot that is shown as finalized is the first slot in the finalized epoch.

author: potuz
content: The specs do not have a notion of an Epoch being finalized. We finalize `Checkpoints` these are a pair `(Root, Epoch)` of a root of a block, and an epoch. It is required that the corresponding block, with root `Root` is the highest block with slot lower or equal to `32*Epoch`. Every ancestor of that block is finalized

author: potuz
content: a block is an ancestor of itself

author: potuz
content: yeah I guess there's no formal definition of ancestor in the spec

author: potuz
content: but right, any block in the canonical chain before or equal to the block is finalized

author: potuz
content: In the example above, the block at slot 4,710,272 has slot exactly equal to 32*147196, therefore can be used as a root for a checkpoint with epoch 147196, any ancestor of it (itself included) is final, and the descendants not necessarily until we finalize another checkpoint in the future

author: smixxtape
content: Ok so my mental model was incorrect then which was what I assumed when I posed the question. Thank you for explaining
